corpus.text: Modus ponens (Latin: 'method of affirming') is a fundamental rule of inference in propositional logic. Form: From premises (1) P→Q (conditional/implication) and (2) P (antecedent), validly conclude Q (consequent). Symbolic notation: ((P→Q) ∧ P) ⊢ Q or {P→Q, P} ⊢ Q. Truth-preserving: if premises true, conclusion must be true. Natural deduction: elimination rule for implication. Distinction from fallacies: (a) Affirming consequent: ((P→Q) ∧ Q) ⊢ P is INVALID, (b) Denying antecedent: ((P→Q) ∧ ¬P) ⊢ ¬Q is INVALID. Related valid form: modus tollens ((P→Q) ∧ ¬Q) ⊢ ¬P. Applications: mathematical proofs, automated theorem proving, expert systems, legal reasoning. In AI: forward chaining in rule-based systems. Philosophical significance: embodies core of deductive reasoning, Kant called it 'analytic'. Limitations: assumes classical logic, in quantum logic may not hold. Historical: known to Stoics, formalized by medieval scholastics, central to modern symbolic logic.
